definitions.definition: to become aware of somebody/something by using your eyes
definitions.sensetop: see somebody/somethingsee (that)…see what, how, etc…see somebody/something + adj.see somebody/something doing somethingsee somebody/something do somethingsomebody/something is seen to do somethingsee + adv./prep.

examples.text: She looked for him but couldn't see him in the crowd.
I looked out of the window but saw nothing.
The opera was the place to **see and be seen** *(= by other important or fashionable people)*.
I **would like to see** some proof of this statement.
The divers **reported seeing** a lot of sharks.
He **recalls seeing** his father sitting at the kitchen table.
I've **never seen** anything like this!
He could see (that) she had been crying.
Did you see what happened?
If you watch carefully, you’ll see how it is done.
I hate to see you unhappy.
She was seen running away from the scene of the crime.
I saw you put the key in your pocket.
He was seen to enter the building about the time the crime was committed.
examples.contextForm: somebody/something is seen to do something

examples.text: The government not only has to do something, it must **be seen to be doing something** *(= people must be aware that it is doing something)*.
The walls were too high to see over.
A dolphin? Oh, let me see!
I can't wait to see his face!
I could see the boat clearly now.
We could just see the hotel in the distance.
The star is bright enough to see with the naked eye.
I know it's hard to believe but I saw it with my own eyes.
He was surprised to see Lucy standing there.
I looked up, only to see Tommy chatting to someone.
I'd love to see her win the gold medal.
It's nice to see the children playing together.
He didn't live to see his grandchildren.

definitions.definition: to have or use the power of sight

examples.text: She will never see again *(= she has become blind)*.
On a clear day you **can see** for miles from here.
It was getting dark and I **couldn't see** to read.
I could hardly see because of the smoke.

definitions.definition: to watch a game, television programme, performance, etc.

examples.text: Did you see that programme on Brazil last night?
In the evening we went to see a movie.
Fifty thousand people saw the match.
I finally got to see them in concert.
I really **want to see** this film now.
This performance was very beautiful, like nothing I had **ever seen** before.
I **remember seeing** that movie when I was a kid.
It's not the sort of thing you see on TV that often.
This film really deserves to be seen on a big screen.

definitions.definition: to look at something in order to find information; to go to somebody in order to ask for help or information

examples.text: See page 158.
If you missed the session, see a member of staff for advice.
See Table 2 for details.
**See also** paragraphs 6.5 to 6.9 above.
**See above/below** for a breakdown of the costs.
See over *(= the next page)* for details.

definitions.definition: to be near and recognize somebody; to meet somebody by chance

examples.text: Guess who I saw at the party last night!
Aren't you pleased to see me?
It's so good to see you!

definitions.definition: to visit somebody/something

examples.text: Come and see us again soon.
Around 200  000 visitors each year come to see the summer palace.
Veronica came to see him in prison.
He said he'd been to see his sister.

definitions.definition: to have a meeting with somebody

examples.text: You ought to see a doctor about that cough.
What is it you want to see me about?
I can only see you for five minutes.
When was the last time you saw a dentist?
She's gone to see the mechanic about getting her car repaired.
Logan came around to see me about a job.
I'm here to see Lisa Daniels.
He came over to see me after my surgery.

definitions.definition: to spend time with somebody

examples.text: **Are you seeing anyone** *(= having a romantic relationship with anyone)*?
They've been **seeing a lot of each other** *(= spending a lot of time together)* recently.
We **haven't seen much of** Liz lately.
He has changed since his family last saw him.

definitions.definition: to understand something

examples.text: ‘It opens like this.’ ‘Oh, **I see**.’
He didn't see the joke.
I don't think she **saw the point** of the story.
He changed the way we **see the world** around us.
to **see a/the need** for something
I **see no need** to involve the law.
I can see both sides of the argument.
They **saw nothing wrong **with having three cars.
Make Lydia **see reason** *(= be sensible)*, will you?
**Can’t you see** (that) he’s taking advantage of you?
I **don't see that it matters** what Josh thinks.
‘It's broken.’ ‘Oh yes, **I see what you mean**.’
‘Can we go swimming?’ ‘**I don't see why not** *(= yes, you can)*.’
They will be able to see what really happened there.
I can see why you were so angry about it.
I don't see why she should get more money than the others.
I fail to see how this idea will help anyone.
It is difficult to see how to get around this problem.
He doesn't see how important this is.
I don't quite see what he's getting at.
I don't think she saw the point of the story.

definitions.definition: to have an opinion of something

examples.text: I **see things** differently now.
Try to see things from her point of view.
**The way I see it**, you have three main problems.
**As far as I can see** *(= in my opinion)*, you've done nothing wrong.
Lack of money is the main problem, **as I see it** *(= in my opinion)*.
She is in love with him but Darren **sees** their relationship **in a different light** *(= has a different opinion)*.

definitions.definition: to consider something as a future possibility; to imagine somebody/something as something
definitions.sensetop: see somebody/something/yourself doing somethingsee somebody/something/yourself as something

examples.text: I can't see her changing her mind.
I can't really see myself working in a lab all day.
His colleagues see him as a future director.
She was quiet and withdrawn and never saw herself as a dancer.

definitions.definition: to find out something by looking, asking or waiting
definitions.sensetop: see what, how, etc…see (that)…it is seen that…

examples.text: ‘Has the mail come yet?’ ‘I'll just go and see.’
‘Is he going to get better?’ ‘I don't know, we'll just have to **wait and see**.’
We'll have a great time, **you'll see**.
Go and see what the kids are doing, will you?
We'll have to **see how it goes**.
It will be **interesting to see** what happens.
I see (that) interest rates are going up again.
**It can be seen that** certain groups are more at risk than others.
He came over to see what was going on.
I want to see how they'll react.
She turned to see who it was.
I'm glad to see that you're keeping well.
You can see at a glance if all is well.

definitions.definition: to find out or decide something by thinking or considering

examples.text: ‘Will you be able to help us?’ ‘I don't know, I'll have to see.’
‘Can I go to the party?’ ‘**We'll see** *(= I'll decide later)*.’
**I'll see what I can do** to help.

definitions.definition: to make sure that you do something or that something is done

examples.text: See that all the doors are locked before you leave.
Could you see that the kids are in bed by 8 o'clock?

definitions.definition: to experience or suffer something

examples.text: He has seen a great deal in his long life.
I hope I never live to **see the day** when computers finally replace books.
It didn't surprise her—she **had seen it all before**.
He saw first-hand the impact of colonialism.
We expect to see an increase of 50–60%.

definitions.definition: to be the time when an event happens

examples.text: Next year sees the centenary of Saint-Saëns' death.
The twentieth century **saw** dramatic **changes** in most areas of life.

definitions.definition: to be the place where an event happens

examples.text: This stadium has seen many thrilling football games.

definitions.definition: to go with somebody to help or protect them

examples.text: I saw the children across *(= helped them cross)* the road.
May I **see you home** *(= go with you as far as your house)*?
My secretary will **see you out** *(= show you the way out of the building)*.

definitions.definition: that can be seen clearly; in a way that can be seen clearly
used when you are thinking or trying to remember something

examples.text: Now let me see—how old is she now?

definitions.definition: to realize that there is going to be a problem before it happens

examples.text: We should have seen it coming. There was no way he could keep going under all that pressure.

definitions.definition: to realize that somebody/something is not as good, pleasant, etc. as they/it seem
to find out or look at something yourself in order to be sure that what somebody is saying is true

examples.text: If you don't believe me, go and see for yourself!

definitions.definition: because of the fact that…

examples.text: Seeing that he's been off sick all week he's unlikely to come.

definitions.definition: goodbye

examples.text: I'd better be going now. See you!

definitions.definition: used when you are explaining something

examples.text: You see, the thing is, we won't be finished before Friday.

wordOrigin: verb Old English sēon, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch zien and German sehen, perhaps from an Indo-European root shared by Latin sequi ‘follow’.
